column4: has introduced the Limiting Emergency Powers Act of 2025
column5: aiming to amend the National Emergencies Act. The bill seeks to terminate any national emergency declared by the President after 30 days unless a joint resolution affirming the declaration is enacted into law.

column1: This legislation was introduced in response to growing concerns about the expansive power granted to the executive branch during national emergencies. Supporters argue that such power can be misused
column2: bypassing essential checks and balances in governance. By limiting emergency declarations to a 30-day period without Congressional approval
column3: the bill intends to encourage legislative oversight and ensure that emergency measures are not extended indefinitely without proper justification.

column1: The potential impact of this bill could reshape how emergencies are managed in the United States. If enacted
column2: it would compel future administrations to present their cases for ongoing emergencies to Congress
column3: fostering accountability. Additionally
column4: it could lead to a reexamination of current national emergency declarations
column5: some of which have persisted for years without active Congressional review.

column3: reflecting a heightened desire among lawmakers to regain authority in emergency situations. The bill has been referred to the House Committees on Transportation and Infrastructure
